content.description: After starting up the obvious left-angling crack step right to the large gully with wide cracks in the center of the wall.  Mostly very easy terrain after the start.  The crux move is at a steep bulge about 3/4 of the way up.
content.protection: The upper section of this will easily eat up a rack of large gear. 1" to 5" pieces. Save a 3"-ish piece for the crux.
content.location: Starts on the most obvious large left-angling crack in the center of the wall (left of the huge corner).  Head towards the alcove with the bolted anchor - shares with High Weed Glutin.  Lower off.  70m or double ropes mandatory.

content.description: A really fun series of assorted hand-cracks and bulges going up the center of the wall ending on a ledge left of the alcove.
content.protection: Ample cam and stopper options. Lots of hand-sized pieces. Gear anchor.  Bring a cordalette and a 70 meter rope if you want to set up a TR. Walk off left side.
content.location: Left and center of the huge corner . The book showed the start of this climb as the left-most(thinner) of the three left-angling cracks but we used the more obvious/logical largest angling crack which is the actually the start of Wheaties.  Looked more fun and easier to protect.

content.description: Start up a left-angling seam then wander up a series of bulges and discontinuous finger-cracks. There's probably a few variations, but we aimed to link up the most obvious cracks. Small cruxes at a small slab step-across and the start.  All in all a quality climb worth a run.  Shares the anchor with Wheaties.
content.protection: Basic rack.  Bring stoppers and finger-sized pieces.
content.location: Starts on the left-angling crack just left of the huge corner.  Bolted anchor in the alcove.  70m or double ropes mandatory.

content.description: Starts on slab section left of Frosted Flakes. Even pace of moderate slab and crack to start, then kicks back at the end with a 10ft lieback section that marks a two part crux. Can protect the first 10a move from a solid stance, moving quickly to protect the second 10a move for a bouldery finish.
content.protection: Gear to 2". Gear anchor below just the lip.
content.location: Left of Frosted Flakes. Easy 5th class to top out through huecos and meat anchor the second. Walk off.

content.description: The book shows going up a unprotected face, but if you stay a little to the left there is a crack you can put some gear in and then traverse right across a horizontal crack. Then the crux: pull over a bulge and then cruise up a fun had crack to the arch.
content.protection: Normal rack. A long web-o-let or cordalet is nice to sling the arch and belay from.
content.location:
Right under the arch on the left side of the wall.

Easy walk off to the left.

content.description:
This is an easier hybrid route of two existing routes ending at the anchor rather than topping out. Kinda a nice variation if you don't want to do the 10a finish or have to do the walk off. We actually really enjoyed this and found it a great lead.

The book shows a blank slab start for Granola Crunch, but it's so close to the corner - it's pretty hard to resist the line of least resistance up the right side. Start up the giant corner (Frosted Flakes start) protects with a couple small nuts, then traverse left (crux)to join Granola Crunch. Follow the obvious discontinuous cracks then traverse left at the top directly to the bolted anchor.  Slabby transition traverse is spicy, but short and sweet.
content.protection: Small to medium stoppers.  Gear to 2"  Shares anchor with Wheaties and High Weed Glutin.
content.location: Starts up the giant corner then traverses left to join Granola Crunch.  Traverse left at the finish to end at the bolted anchor in the alcove rather than finishing up the 10a crack.
